articles.title: Resources to help you begin your coding journey
articles.contents:
RStudio Cloud
In the workshops, we will use RStudio Cloud, which is a “lightweight, cloud-based solution that allows anyone to do, share, teach and learn data science online”. This will allow us to share all of our code online and will make it easier for us to help answer all of your coding questions.
This platform is completely free for you to use, but you will need to set up an account. To do so, please follow the instructions below:
Go to your email and find the invitation to RStudio Cloud and open the link (we will let you know when we’ve sent you the invite)
Click “Sign Up” and enter your details (email, create a password, name)
Once you do this, you’ll have to go back to your email and verify your account/email address
Navigate back to the RStudio Cloud page and click “Continue”
You should be set! To confirm, go to the “Members” tab and search for your name on the members list and check that you have the role “contributor”
Feel free to also check out the About tab
If you have any issues, please let us know on Slack
R & RStudio
RStudio Cloud is great for beginners and getting started with R, but you will eventually want to work on your own computers. So, after the first couple of workshops, we will show you how to transfer all of your files to your local computers (as opposed to working on the cloud). To do this, you will need to have both R and RStudio installed.
Please have these installed/downloaded before Workshop #3
You can install R from the CRAN (Comprehensive R Archive Network) website. I suggest downloading the latest version, which (as of the time of writing this workshop) is R 4.1.1
R for Windows link
R for Mac link

You can download RStudio here
Although you need to have R installed, you will mostly likely never need to open R because you can do everything you need in RStudio
Additional R Resources
R-Ladies Sydney RYouWithMe Tutorials. There are 4 different units within these tutorials:
BasicBasics includes a tour of RStudio, how to install and load packages, and how to get data into RStudio
CleanItUp introduces a few very popular packages (including tidyverse which we will learn all about!) and how to use a few functions to “wrangle” (or clean and organize) your data
VizWhiz introduces ggplot and gives examples of how to plot data to create beautiful visualisations in R
MarkyMark introduces R Markdown (which we will also learn all about!)

Feel free to check out a blog post written by Jenny on Introduction to R. Some of the topics covered include: getting familiar with RStudio, working directories, R Markdown, and tidyverse!

articles.title: Welcome to the NEWScribo Website!
Projects
articles.description: Working in small groups, you will have a chance to choose your own research question from either a dataset on the Olympics or a dataset on Climate Change. Using your new R skills, you will work together to analyse the data and even create graphs to answer your research question. We will post all of your analyses and results here!

articles.title: Workshop 1: Introducing the Datasets
articles.contents:
As we mentioned in the first workshop, you will work on a research project in small groups. We saw quite a few of you were interested in sports and climate change, so we’ve selected two potential data sets for you to use for your projects. All of this data is from the “tidytuesday” Github repository - so it’s all free and open source. Tidy Tuesday is a “weekly social data project focused on using tidyverse packages to clean, wrangle, tidy, and plot a new dataset every Tuesday.” These are two data sets that were used in the past.
The Olympics: “This is a historical dataset on the modern Olympic Games, including all the Games from Athens 1896 to Rio 2016”. You can find more information about this data set here
Australia Rainfall: This data is “all about Australia, including it’s climate over time”. You can find more information about this data set here
The Olympics Data


# install.packages("tidyverse")
 
library(tidyverse) # we need this package to read in our data

olympics <- read_csv("olympics.csv") # read in the olympics data

reactable::reactable(head(olympics, 20), defaultPageSize=5) # create table to view top 20 rows

articles.title: Workshop 2: R Syntax and Packages
articles.contents:
In this workshop, we learned about the syntax of R, including several common operators, vectors, and different types of variables. We also briefly introduced Tidyverse and discussed packages and how to install and load (or call) in the libraries for the packages you want to use.
Before we get started, here are the instructions if you want to change your R Markdown preferences to print your code in the console as opposed to directly below the R chunk: Tools -> Global Options -> R Markdown -> uncheck where is says “show output inline for all…”
Syntax
Syntax in computer programming is a set of rules that defines the structure of a language, similar to how we have rules for grammar and spelling. If you write a sentence with incorrect spelling or grammar, the sentence may not make sense. If you write code without proper syntax, the code won’t be able to run and you’ll get an error message.
Operators


x <- 10 # assignment operator
y <- 25
z <- 100

x > y # greater than operator: 10 > 25?


[1] FALSE

x < y  # less than operator


[1] TRUE

# x = y
x == y # equality operator


[1] FALSE

x != y # not equal to operator 


[1] TRUE

z > 50 & z < 200 # & is the "and" operator


[1] TRUE

z > 50 & z > 200


[1] FALSE

z > 50 | z > 200 # | is the "or" operator


[1] TRUE

Vectors
In R, a vector is the simplest type of data structure. It is “a single entity consisting of a collection of things”


names <- c("Kevin", "Jenny", "Millie")

age <- c(20, 18, 33)

blue_eyes <- c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE)



Types of Variables



typeof(names)


[1] "character"

typeof(age)


[1] "double"

typeof(blue_eyes)


[1] "logical"

Tidyverse
Tidyverse is a package, well it’s actually a collection of 8 packages (ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr, readr, purrr, tibble, stringr, forcats) introduced by Hadley Wickham to help with data manipulation, exploration, and visualisation
You can check out the tidyverse https://www.tidyverse.org/packages/ to find out more details of each of the individual packages

Packages
Remember, a package is a collections of code, data, and documentation all bundled together in a standardized way that can be easily shared and installed by other R users
Installing packages: when you want to use a package for the first time, you must install the package with install.packages("package_name") - note the package name must be in quotes. You only need to install a package 1 time on your local computer, so I suggest using the console to install packages
Loading packages/libraries: every time you start a new session, you have to tell R what packages you want to load in. You do this with the library(package_name) - note the package name does not need to be in quotes here
Whenever you load tidyverse, you will see a message saying it’s attaching all 8 packages. Therefore, you don’t have to load in any of the individual packages because they all get called in together. This means as long as you load in tidyverse, you can use functions from any one of the 8 packages
We will use the tidyverse and palmerpenguins packages


# install.packages("tidyverse") # run in console
# install.packages("palmerpenguins")

library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)
penguins


# A tibble: 344 x 8
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA
 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193
 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190
 7 Adelie  Torgersen           38.9          17.8               181
 8 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195
 9 Adelie  Torgersen           34.1          18.1               193
10 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190
# ... with 334 more rows, and 3 more variables: body_mass_g <int>,
#   sex <fct>, year <int>

articles.title: Workshop 3: Data Frames and Data Manipulation
articles.contents:
In this workshop, we first learned about dataframes and tibbles and then discussed data manipulation. We introduced the pipe %>% operator and went through the first research question using the olympics dataset: How many gold medals has Australia won each year we have recorded?
Although we won’t have time to go through all of the functions you may need, but here’s a cheat sheet with some of the more popular functions https://docs.google.com/document/d/1zEP36GwV3XfPI3FB9b64ckRLkZTkYs27jX7eBzFHvNQ/edit
Load libraries
As always, the first thing we need to do is load in the libraries (or packages) we want to use


library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)



Data frames
what is a data frame?
a data frame is a common way of storing data in R. Data frames can have variables are different types (e.g. one variable may be a character and one may be numeric)

here, we will explore the penguins dataset that is included in the palmerpenguins package, so once you load the library you can take a look at penguins
how can we interpret this data?
each row is a unique penguin
each column is a variable that provides information about the penguin

we can see this is a data frame and it actually tells us penguins is specifically a “tibble”
tibbles are simple data frames with some features that make working with the data really nice
shows us exactly how big our dataset is (344 rows and 8 columns)
automatically only prints out the first 10 rows, so we can always see the variable names at the top
under each variable name, we see what type of variable it is (i.e. fct, dbl, int)



penguins


# A tibble: 344 x 8
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           40.3          18                 195
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           NA            NA                  NA
 5 Adelie  Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193
 6 Adelie  Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190
 7 Adelie  Torgersen           38.9          17.8               181
 8 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195
 9 Adelie  Torgersen           34.1          18.1               193
10 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190
# ... with 334 more rows, and 3 more variables: body_mass_g <int>,
#   sex <fct>, year <int>

is.data.frame(penguins)


[1] TRUE

is_tibble(penguins)


[1] TRUE

is.data.frame(names)


[1] FALSE

Create our own tibble
let’s combine the vectors we created in the previous workshop into a tibble using tibble()


names <- c("Kevin", "Jenny", "Millie")
age <- c(20, 18, 33)
blue_eyes <- c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE)

my_tibble <- tibble(
  Name = names,
  Age = age,
  Blue_eye = blue_eyes
)

is.data.frame(my_tibble)


[1] TRUE

is_tibble(my_tibble)


[1] TRUE

my_tibble$Name[1]


[1] "Kevin"

my_tibble[1,3]


# A tibble: 1 x 1
  Blue_eye
  <lgl>   
1 TRUE    

Data Manipulation
Read in data


olympics <- read_csv("olympics.csv")
olympics


# A tibble: 271,116 x 15
      id name      sex     age height weight team   noc   games   year
   <dbl> <chr>     <chr> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>  <dbl>
 1     1 A Dijiang M        24    180     80 China  CHN   1992 ~  1992
 2     2 A Lamusi  M        23    170     60 China  CHN   2012 ~  2012
 3     3 Gunnar N~ M        24     NA     NA Denma~ DEN   1920 ~  1920
 4     4 Edgar Li~ M        34     NA     NA Denma~ DEN   1900 ~  1900
 5     5 Christin~ F        21    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1988 ~  1988
 6     5 Christin~ F        21    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1988 ~  1988
 7     5 Christin~ F        25    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1992 ~  1992
 8     5 Christin~ F        25    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1992 ~  1992
 9     5 Christin~ F        27    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1994 ~  1994
10     5 Christin~ F        27    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1994 ~  1994
# ... with 271,106 more rows, and 5 more variables: season <chr>,
#   city <chr>, sport <chr>, event <chr>, medal <chr>

What is your research question?
How many gold medals has Australia won each year we have recorded?
The pipe %>% operator
the pipe is part of the tidyverse language and we will use it all the time!
you use the pipe when you want to execute multiple operations in a specific sequence. To me, it makes sense to think about the pipe as “AND THEN”
Research Question #1
How many gold medals has Australia won each year we have recorded?


my_olympics <- olympics %>% 
  select(noc, year, medal) %>% 
  filter(noc == "AUS") %>% 
  filter(medal == "Gold") %>% 
  na.omit()

my_olympics %>% 
  count(medal) 


# A tibble: 1 x 2
  medal     n
  <chr> <int>
1 Gold    348

my_olympics %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  count(medal) %>% # medals *for each year* because we used group_by()
  arrange(desc(n))


# A tibble: 25 x 3
# Groups:   year [25]
    year medal     n
   <dbl> <chr> <int>
 1  2000 Gold     60
 2  2004 Gold     49
 3  1996 Gold     32
 4  2008 Gold     31
 5  1956 Gold     28
 6  2016 Gold     23
 7  1988 Gold     18
 8  2012 Gold     18
 9  1992 Gold     14
10  1960 Gold     11
# ... with 15 more rows

articles.title: Workshop 4: Research Question #3
articles.contents:
In this workshop, we first reviewed the code for Research Question #1 and discussed the importance of “commenting” our code (aka leaving notes for ourselves in the future). Although we didn’t have time to go through the code for Research Question #2, you can find the code in the workshop2_answers.Rmd on RStudio cloud.
We spent the majority of our time working through Research Question #3: Is there a relationship between height and weight for basketball players (both male and female)? With this research question, we talked about the concept of a correlation.
We spent the remaining time working in your groups to discuss ideas for your own research question.
Load libraries
As always, the first thing we need to do is load in the libraries (or packages) we want to use


library(tidyverse)



Read in data


olympics <- read_csv("olympics.csv")
olympics


# A tibble: 271,116 x 15
      id name      sex     age height weight team   noc   games   year
   <dbl> <chr>     <chr> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>  <dbl>
 1     1 A Dijiang M        24    180     80 China  CHN   1992 ~  1992
 2     2 A Lamusi  M        23    170     60 China  CHN   2012 ~  2012
 3     3 Gunnar N~ M        24     NA     NA Denma~ DEN   1920 ~  1920
 4     4 Edgar Li~ M        34     NA     NA Denma~ DEN   1900 ~  1900
 5     5 Christin~ F        21    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1988 ~  1988
 6     5 Christin~ F        21    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1988 ~  1988
 7     5 Christin~ F        25    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1992 ~  1992
 8     5 Christin~ F        25    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1992 ~  1992
 9     5 Christin~ F        27    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1994 ~  1994
10     5 Christin~ F        27    185     82 Nethe~ NED   1994 ~  1994
# ... with 271,106 more rows, and 5 more variables: season <chr>,
#   city <chr>, sport <chr>, event <chr>, medal <chr>

Research Question 3
Is there a relationship between height and weight for basketball players (both male and female)?


olympics %>%
  select(sex, height, weight, sport) %>%
  na.omit() %>%
  filter(sport == "Basketball") %>%
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(correlation = cor(height, weight)) 


# A tibble: 2 x 2
  sex   correlation
  <chr>       <dbl>
1 F           0.796
2 M           0.831
